sn22.80:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans, near Kapilavatthu in the Banyan Tree Monastery.
sn22.80:1.2: Then the Buddha, having dismissed the mendicant Saṅgha for some reason, robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Kapilavatthu for alms.
sn22.80:1.3: He wandered for alms in Kapilavatthu. After the meal, on his return from almsround, he went to the Great Wood for the day’s meditation,
sn22.80:1.4: plunged deep into it, and sat at the root of a young wood-apple tree to meditate.
sn22.80:2.1: Then as he was in private retreat this thought came to his mind,
sn22.80:2.3: But there are mendicants here who are junior, recently gone forth, newly come to this teaching and training.
sn22.80:2.4: Not seeing me they may change and fall apart.
sn22.80:2.5: If a young calf doesn’t see its mother it may change and fall apart. …
sn22.80:2.7: Or if young seedlings don’t get water they may change and fall apart.
sn22.80:2.8: In the same way, there are mendicants here who are junior, recently gone forth, newly come to this teaching and training.
sn22.80:2.9: Not seeing me they may change and fall apart.
sn22.80:2.10: Why don’t I support the mendicant Saṅgha now as I did in the past?”
sn22.80:3.1: Then the divinity Sahampati knew what the Buddha was thinking. As easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, he vanished from the realm of divinity and reappeared in front of the Buddha.
sn22.80:3.2: He arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha, and said:
sn22.80:3.3: “That’s so true, Blessed One! That’s so true, Holy One!
sn22.80:3.4: The Buddha has purged the mendicant Saṅgha.
sn22.80:3.5: But there are mendicants who are junior, recently gone forth, newly come to this teaching and training. …
sn22.80:3.11: May the Buddha be happy with the mendicant Saṅgha!
sn22.80:3.12: May the Buddha welcome the mendicant Saṅgha!
sn22.80:3.13: May the Buddha support the mendicant Saṅgha now as he did in the past!”
sn22.80:4.2: Then the divinity Sahampati, knowing that the Buddha had consented, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before vanishing right there.
sn22.80:5.1: Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of retreat and went to the Banyan Tree Monastery, where he sat on the seat spread out.
sn22.80:5.2: Then he used his psychic power to will that the mendicants would come to him timidly, alone or in pairs.
sn22.80:5.3: Those mendicants approached the Buddha timidly, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to them:
sn22.80:6.1: “This is the last of lifestyles, mendicants, namely relying on alms.
sn22.80:6.2: The world curses you: ‘You beggar, walking bowl in hand!’
sn22.80:6.3: Yet earnest gentlemen take it up for a good reason.
sn22.80:6.4: Not to escape a summons by a king or a summons for a bandit, or because you were in debt or in fear, or in order to make a living.
sn22.80:6.5: But because they’re swamped by rebirth, old age, and death; by sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. They’re swamped by suffering, mired in suffering.
sn22.80:6.6: And they think, ‘Hopefully I can make an end to this entire mass of suffering.’
sn22.80:7.1: That’s how this gentleman has gone forth.
sn22.80:7.2: Yet they covet sensual pleasures; they’re infatuated, full of ill will and malicious intent. They are unmindful, lacking situational awareness and immersion, with straying mind and undisciplined faculties.
sn22.80:7.3: Suppose there was a firebrand for lighting a funeral pyre, burning at both ends, and smeared with dung in the middle. It couldn’t be used as timber either in the village or the wilderness.
sn22.80:7.4: I say that individual is just like this. They’ve missed out on the pleasures of the lay life, and haven’t fulfilled the goal of the ascetic life.
sn22.80:8.1: There are these three unskillful thoughts.
sn22.80:8.3: And where do these three unskillful thoughts cease without anything left over?
sn22.80:8.4: In those who meditate with their mind firmly established in the four kinds of mindfulness meditation; or who develop signless immersion.
sn22.80:8.5: This is quite enough motivation to develop signless immersion.
sn22.80:8.6: When signless immersion is developed and cultivated it is very fruitful and beneficial.
sn22.80:9.2: Views favoring existence and views favoring nonexistence.
sn22.80:9.3: A learned noble disciple reflects on this:
sn22.80:9.4: ‘Is there anything in the world that I could grasp without fault?’
sn22.80:9.6: ‘There’s nothing in the world that I could grasp without fault.
sn22.80:9.7: For in grasping I would grasp only at form, feeling,
sn22.80:9.10: That grasping of mine would be a condition for continued existence.
sn22.80:9.11: Continued existence is a requirement for rebirth.
sn22.80:9.12: Rebirth is a requirement for old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress to come to be.
sn22.80:9.13: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.’
sn22.80:10.4: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”
sn22.80:10.6: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:
sn22.80:10.7: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
sn22.80:10.15: They understand: ‘… there is nothing further for this place.’”
